results.title: Heaven and earth
results.creator_credit: Carol Stowe, Peter Swain, Lois Bianchi, WNET (Television station : New York, N.Y.), Thirteen, Educational Broadcasting and Granada Television International
results.brief_description:
Episode number 1 of Series “The Shape of the world”.
Heaven and earth traces the way in which mankind’s earliest ideas of the world emerged - sometimes from imagination, sometimes from scientific observation, often from the need of rulers to know their domains in detail. It looks at the earliest concepts of the world’s shape, from Pythagoras, Eristosthenes, and Ptolomy, whose work was rediscovered as the Renaissance flowered, to the ancient Chinese who developed quite different ideas about the shape of the world. Narrated and introduced by Patrick Stewart.

results.title: Heaven's My Destination
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Everyman”.
Since returning from the moon many astronauts have testified to the strong spiritual impact the space experience has had on them. A number have committed themselves to Christ and Ed Mitchell has founded the Institute of Noetic Sciences. This program looks at how space travel has given these men a new perception of man’s place in the universe.

results.title: Heaven's gate
results.creator_credit: Michael Cimino, Joan Carell and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Heaven’s gate is one of the most talked-about films in cinema history and based on events which occurred in Wyoming in 1892 when ruthless ranchers decided to kill starving immigrants who had been stealing cattle. Kris Kristofferson and Christopher Walken play lawman and hitman on opposite sides of the struggle, who share the love of Ella, played by Isabelle Huppert. The original film was cut by 70 minutes and was never acclaimed in the United States as it was in Europe. This version is presented in its entirety and has compelling performances by the supporting cast of John Hurt, Jeff Bridges and Sam Waterston and locational shoots of breathtaking beauty.

results.title: Heaven's burning
results.creator_credit: Craig Lahiff, Al Clark, Helen Leake and Dup Art
results.brief_description: Midori (Yuki Kudoh) is a young Japanese bride, who, despising her new husband, decides to flee him on their wedding night. Faking her own kidnapping, and stranded in Sydney, Midori is then the victim of a real kidnap attempt during a violent bank robbery. Shw ends up on the road with the handsome getaway driver Colin (Russell Crowe), who saves her from execution at the hands of his cohorts, betraying them in the process. Pursued by the police, Midori’s enraged husband and Colin’s murderous gang, Colin and Midori flee towards the outback. En route the pair meet a slew of eccentric characters, attend a B and S ball and have a variety of experiences, which unites them romantically. “Heaven’s burning” is a road movie, and typically of the Australian genre, has the action contained within a deterministically peculiar outback culture. Midori’s ethnicity serves as a conduit on which to channel a range of unoriginal Aussie stereotypes, as well as highlighting racism and cultural intolerance. The film is a mix of genres - romance, crime flick, thriller - and is slavish in its desire to appear offbeat and original. Cast also includes Kenji Isomura, Ray Barrett and Robert Mammone.

results.title: Heaven
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: Surfing, sexuality and masculine bodies beneath the female gaze. A handheld camera closes in on private space of surfers as they disrobe in carparks and attempts to catch them ‘out’. Filmed in and around Sydney beaches, Moffatt and female friends have documented a playful but edgey representation of surfer culture as the interaction between the filmmaker and subject moves towards active voyerism. The heavy drum beats and lapping waves of the soundtrack mirror the thrill and excitement of gender mis-representation. How do the males react, or perform, on camera and how do audiences interpret their own voyeuristic desires? What does it suggest about the role of the film maker, of ethics or ‘surveillance’?

results.title: Heatwave
results.creator_credit: Phil Noyce, Ross Matthews, Hilary Linstead and Heatwave Films Pty Ltd, Sydney Australia F F P A A
results.brief_description: A suspenseful thriller about a woman who cared too much about people, their lives and their homes, and a man who had a job to do and wouldn’t be swayed by emotions. She represented the people, he represented power and corruption and together they were heading towards trouble. Cast includes Judy Davis, Richard Moir, Chris Haywood, Bill Hunter and John Meillon. PLEASE NOTE: THE 16MM PRINT OF THIS FILM HAS NORWEGIAN SUBTITLES

results.title: Heathlands
results.brief_description: The first section studies the geology of the dry, sandy heathlands typical of south-eastern England and part of northern France. The second section introduces flora typical of the uncultivated heathlands and the final section deals with the fauna of the heathlands.

results.title: Heathers
results.creator_credit: Michael Lehmann, Denise Di Novi, Cinemarque Entertainment and New World Pictures
results.brief_description: This black comedy about high school politics, teenage suicide and trendy cliques, focuses on the ‘Heathers’, three of the prettiest and most popular rich girls at Westerbury High School, home of preppies, nerds and trendies. They set the trends, make the rules and devise ways of making life hell for the other students. That is until Heather No.4 who is really a Veronica, (Winona Ryder), teams up with her boyfriend, JD, a rebellious new student (Christian Slater), to change all the rules and seek revenge. An ultimate revenge fantasy which has become a “cult” movie. Also stars Shannen Doherty.

results.title: Heather Locklear chocolate
results.brief_description: Award-winning comedy about a gender-bending teenager (Einar Johansen) and his passion for nail polish. Each of his favorites has a story behind it, however his ‘holy grail’ of nail polishes is a colour worn by Heather Locklear in ‘Melrose Place’.

results.title: Heather's case (Captioned)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Improving Performance”.
The youngest clerical worker in a project team is angry about staff who are inconsiderate, messy and who avoid her whilst her colleagues have complained to the new supervisor about her being aggressive. The supervisor attempts to resolve the problem and then Peter Quarry assumes the role of supervisor and uses the 3 step approach.
